abstract.text: An ISO 7816 card emulation session.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Use an instance of
to perform
protocol communication with an NFC reader, receiving and responding to Application Protocol Data Units (APDUs) in your app.

supports host card emulation (HCE) transactions for in-store payments, car keys, closed-loop transit, corporate badges, hotel keys, merchant loyalty/rewards and event tickets in the European Economic Area (EEA).
Use a card session to perform card emulation when in the presence of an NFC reader. You do this by managing the session as follows:
Verify that the system is eligible to use
. Check
and
to ensure that the device supports card sessions with NFC. Also check
to verify that the system supports card session use in the current environment. Don’t continue unless all of these values are
Create a card session with
and begin iterating over events from the session’s
. Starting the session acquires necessary system resources and posts
to the event stream when the app acquires the NFC resource. After this, the session sends the
event when the device detects the RF field of an NFC reader.
Start card emulation by calling
when your app is ready to handle APDUs from the reader. You typically do this after receiving the

, but you can start emulation regardless of whether a reader is present. After you start emulation, the reader (if present) can communicate with the card, and emulation triggers the system modal UI to display over the app.
At this point, begin receiving and processing APDUs from the event stream. Process the APDU
in each event, generate a response, and send it with
. If you don’t respond in a timely manner to every event, the reader might treat it as a timeout condition and fail with an error.
Use the
property to provide updates to the person using the app as the communication continues.
If the reader disconnects, possibly because of the device moving away from the reader, handle the event
Stop card emulation by calling
. This shuts down the RF interface and cuts off the RF connection with a reader if one exists.
Invalidate the session with
, which cleans up system resources.
The following example shows a simple interaction with a card session. It attempts to acquire both a
and a
. If both of these succeed, it uses a
loop to process events from the session’s
as it receives them.

code: /// A place-holder function for APDU processing. In a real app,
/// process the received data and return a response as Data.
let ProcessAPDU: (_: Data) -> Data = { capdu in return Data() }
// Proceed only if the current device and system are able and
// Hold a presentment intent assertion reference to prevent the
// default contactless app from launching. In a real app, monitor
// presentmentIntent.isValid to ensure the assertion remains active.
/// Handle failure to acquire NFC presentment intent assertion or
// Iterate over events as the card session produces them.
for try await event in cardSession.eventStream {
/// Start card emulation on first detection of an external reader.
/// Stop emulation on first notification of RF link loss.
/// Call handler to process received input and produce a response.
/// Handle the error from respond(response:). If the error is
cardSession.alertMessage = String(localized: "Ending communication with card reader.")
/// Handle the reason for session invalidation.
presentmentIntent = nil /// Release presentment intent assertion.

inlineContent.text: Card emulation is valid for up to 60 seconds from the
call. Once the session timeout occurs, the
posts the event
with a
of
. At this point, the session becomes invalidated.
Your app must have the following entitlements to use
A Boolean value that indicates this app can use card sessions.
A string array of ISO 7816 identifier strings that your app listens for when receiving the

command from the reader. These strings can be fully-qualified Application Identifier (AID) strings, Registered Application Provider Identifier (RID) strings, or prefix strings. Any prefix strings must be at least as long as the RID.
If your app lacks a required entitlement,
raises
. To avoid this, check the
and
properties before attempting to create a card session.
Optionally, your app may have the
entitlement. A value of
indicates that a person can use the iOS settings app to set this app as a default NFC contactless app.
For more information and to apply for these entitlements, visit
Use of this entitlement is managed by Apple. It is subject to the terms and conditions agreed to as part of the application process.
To test HCE-based contactless transactions, you’ll need to test with an iPhone and NFC hardware.
requires the presence of an NFC reader, which isn’t supported in Simulator, to perform an ISO 7816 card emulation session.
To learn more about CardSession requirements, see

inlineContent.overridingTitle: HCE-based contactless transactions for banking and wallet apps in the European Economic Area

overridingTitleInlineContent.text: HCE-based contactless transactions for banking and wallet apps in the European Economic Area

abstract.text: Detect NFC tags, read messages that contain NDEF data, and save data to writable tags.
An ISO 7816 card emulation session.
An Application Programming Data Unit (APDU) received from the NFC card reader.
The APDU data received from the NFC reader.
Respond to the session after receiving and processing an APDU.
The final status to show in the user interface when ending card emulation.
An error type that indicates problems with a card session.
The session is no longer valid because it reached its maximum duration.
A type that enumerates events produced by a card session.
The session lost the RF link or the currently-selected Application Identifier (AID) became deselected.
The session detected the RF field of an external NFC reader.
The session became invalid.
The card session successfully started.
An asynchronous sequence of events produced by a card session.
A message to show on the alert action sheet after card emulation starts.
An asynchronous sequence of events from the card session.
Creates a contactless card session.
Invalidates the current card emulation session.
A property that indicates whether the current system supports card session functionality.
A Boolean value that indicates whether emulation is currently active.
A property that indicates whether the current device supports card session functionality.
Start the card emulation and present a modal user interface to the person using the app.
Stop card emulation and display a status.
An object that signals your app’s intention to make exclusive use of the device’s contactless features.
A Boolean value indicating whether your app can use the card session API.
A Boolean value indicating whether your app can be a default app for contactless NFC with the card session API.
An array of identifier strings the app handles with the card session API.
Unconditionally prints a given message and stops execution.
